Award.AwardTitle: Photo-Aligning Molecular Orientations in Liquid Crystal Polymers into Complex Patterns for Programmable Origami

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
As inspired by the Japanese art of paper folding, programmed origami is emerging as a new avenue towards manufacturing three-dimensional objects via autonomous folding of two-dimensional sheets of materials. To realize the programmed origami, a programmable folding mechanism at the small length scales is the key and thus in high demand. Liquid crystal polymers are weakly cross-linked polymers incorporated with rod or disk-like molecular units. When these molecular units are aligned in non-uniform directional patterns, the liquid crystal polymers can be triggered to self-deform by external stimuli such as temperature and light. This award supports fundamental research to develop the needed technology for aligning the molecular orientations in complex patterns in small length scales and to gain basic understanding on how to design molecular orientation patterns to achieve desired three-dimensional microstructures. Three-dimensional microstructures are highly desired in a variety of industrial applications such as sensors, actuators, drug delivery and photonic devices. The outcome from this research should contribute to the U.S. economy and benefit society. This multidisciplinary research provides a great opportunity to educate graduate and undergraduate students with knowledge and skills in photonics, liquid crystal science and technology, nanomanufacturing and numerical modeling, and to enhance diversity by involving minority and high-school students.

Programmed origami promises manufacturing of exotic three-dimensional micro and nanostructures by self-folding of two-dimensional materials or structures. This project aims to develop capabilities to imprint folding trajectories of liquid crystal polymer films in their molecular orientation fields. It will study a novel photo-patterning technique for defining complex molecular orientation order. It will develop a basic understanding of the relationship between molecular orientation and self-folding processes. The research team will (1) design, simulate, fabricate and characterize plasmonic photomasks for desired molecular orientation patterns; (2) develop an optical exposure system for exposing photoalignment materials; and (3) design, model and fabricate liquid crystal polymer films or microstructures with embedded molecular orientational orders and characterize their shape evolution under external stimuli. The proposed photopatterning technique is advantageous in several aspects: capability of large scale patterning, single exposure and scaling-up feasibility. This research will yield both fundamental understanding and new technologies to produce self-folding and twisting microstructures and programmable three-dimensional micro/nanomanufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Origami is a Japanese art of paper folding which can produce highly complex 3D structures by simply folding a sheet of paper.  In this project, we are developing techniques and numerical modeling tools that pave the way to manufacture 3D structures in microscopic scale based on stimuli-responsive liquid crystal elastomers. Liquid crystal elastomers that are weakly cross-linked polymers with molecular units that are oriented locally along a common direction. Liquid crystal elastomers are suitable for autonomous origami because their shape deformations are directedly controlled by molecular orientations; to reach this goal, it is essential to understand what design molecular orientations can lead to target shapes, and to control molecular orientations at will. With this award, we developed a new technique that allows for photopatterning arbitrary designer molecular orientations. This technique is based on engineered photomasks made of nanometer-sized rectangular holes in aluminum films, in which the target molecular orientations are encoded in the orientations of the rectangular holes (see Fig. 1). We established the basic understanding and design rules for such metamasks by numerical and experimental studies, and established procedures to make microstructures of liquid crystal elastomers with predesigned molecular orientations. This photopatterning technique is fast and highly accurate in controlling molecular orientations. We also implemented a 3D director relaxation code in the parallel computing for calculating molecular orientations with predefined boundary conditions as set by the photopatterning technique in experiments. This algorithm is 45 times faster than similar code on a single computer processor and allowed for simulating systems in one hour that used to take nearly two days. The combination of this algorithm with a 3D finite element simulation code for modeling shape changes of liquid crystal elastomers has enabled modeling shape changes of liquid crystal elastomers with arbitrary molecular orientation patterns. These innovations allowed the team to model experiments of liquid crystal polymers that exhibit continuous, directional wave motion under constant illumination and light-driven robotic crawling.  The photopatterning technique for controlling molecular orientations are enabling new applications far beyond the programmed origami, such as the command of the usually chaotic motion of bacteria and the fabrication of high quality micro-optical devices that are highly desired by various healthcare applications. This research project provided a multidisciplinary platform for training students with profound knowledge in liquid crystal science and state-of-the-art nanofabrication and characterization skills: 5 graduate students participated in this project with 3 graduated with doctoral degrees; two undergraduate students and two high school students directly worked on related research. The investigators organized and/or recruited high school students as part-time, for-credit STEM internships at Kent State University through the State of Ohio’s College Credit Plus Program. The internship has significant influenced these students in their college studies as statistics shows that 94% of them have chosen SETM as their majors.
